Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will arrange for a FEOGA grant to be paid by the European Commission to the South West Kerry Development Organisation in respect of the development and erection of a mart in Caherciveen, County Kerry; and if he will make a statement on the matter setting out the present position.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 348, 349 and 353 together.

In August last the co-ordinating bodies for livestock marts made a joint submission to my Department about necessary and desirable improvements at marts and seeking FEOGA aid under Regulation EEC 355/77.

On 21 November Deputy Paddy Hegarty, Minister of State at my Department, met a deputation from these bodies and agreed to the preparation of a draft sectoral programme covering livestock marts. The submission to the EC Commission of such a programme would be a prerequisite to consideration of any individual projects for aid. A working party consisting of officers from my Department and representatives from the mart bodies was set up and is at present compiling data preparatory to the formulation of a sectoral programme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Nobody may be committed to prison merely for non-payment of debt. A person may be committed to prison for failure to comply with a court order to make certain payments in discharge of a debt, an order which may be made only after examination of means designed to establish that the person can pay. Speaker.hpid: Mr. Crowley Mr. Crowley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the total cost of the school built in Lyre, Banteer, County Cork; when it was completed; the total cost of the works done in the school subsequently; and if she will explain the justification for these extra costs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I assume the Deputy's question refers to Lyre national school, Banteer, County Cork. The original school was built in 1950 and an extension thereto was built in 1973. It is my Department's practice to maintain confidentiality with school authorities in relation to the financial details of individual projects. I am satisfied that the school extension which was designed by the school authorities' own consultant was constructed in accordance with accepted building practice at the time, and that grant payments were properly made at the time of construction. My Department has agreed to grant aid necessary remedial works to the roof and windows of the school, and the bulk of the grant payments for which these remedial works were eligible has been paid. I am satisfied that the remedial works also qualified for grant-aid under my Department's scheme of capital grants. Part of the cost of all of the works referred to has been borne by the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she has received representations from the administrator of St. Paul's secondary school, Greenhills, Dublin 12, regarding the revision of the scheme of special grants for certain schools; and if she will make a statement on the matters raised in these representations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department has received representations on behalf of the Advisory Committee of St. Paul's secondary school, Greenhills, Dublin 12, regarding the revision of the scheme of special grants for certain subjects.

The position is that, following many complaints about the operation of the system of payment of these grants, a new system was introduced in 1985 in the interests of equity, simplicity and earlier payment. As a result of the more equitable system of distribution some schools received less and others more than hitherto. The total amount of money paid out for these grants in 1985 was however greater than in any previous year.

A sizeable proportion of the funds available in 1985 had to be devoted to clearing a backlog of claims which brought the system up-to-date for the first time in years. No such backlog of claims remains to form a charge on the funds available to pay these special grants in 1986.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason for the dealy in the provision of five new classrooms and an assembly hall at St. Nissan's national school, Mungret, County Limerick, approval for which has already been given; if she will indicate the date on which work will commence on these; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Following a review of enrolments and of the existing accommodation at St. Nissan's national school, Mungret, County Limerick, my Department on 22 November 1985 advised the school authorities of its agreement to a revised brief for the provision of five new classrooms and a general purposes room and the conversion of an existing general purposes room to a classroom. My Department's professional officers have been instructed to expedite the preparation of the necessary sketch plan, and this will be submitted for consideration by the school authorities as soon as possible. I am not in a position to state at this stage when building work may commence on the project.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason for the inordinate delay in sanctioning the extension to Carrigboy national school, Darrus, County Cork; and if she will give immediate sanction for the commencement of work on this project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The proposal to extend Carrigboy national school, County Cork, and to improve the facilities there, has been accepted in principle by my Department. It was necessary in considering the urgency of the project to carry-out an examination of enrolment trends. Although enrolments have not been up to expectations my Department are satisfied that the project should proceed as soon as the finances available to my Department permit. The question of inviting tenders for the project is under consideration and the outcome will be conveyed as soon as possible to the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The numbers of inspections carried out by officials of my Department under the terms of the Hotels and Catering Joint Labour Committee Orders in 1983, 1984 and 1985 are as follows:

MainHeading.P: There were two prosecutions in 1983 and two in 1984. There were no prosecutions in 1985. Details of the cases in 1983 and 1984 are as follows:
Prosecutions

row.entry:
Employer refused to produce wage records.
Employer prevented employees being interviewed by Inspector.
Defendant pleaded guilty and Probation Act applied.
Employer failed to pay holiday money.
Fined £10 with order to pay holiday money due.
Employer underpaid 3 employees. Inadequate wage records kept by employer. Wages notice (poster) not on display.
Employer fined £75 for underpayments and ordered to pay arrears of wages to the 3 employees and £32 expenses.

Employer fined £50 for underpayments and £20 for not keeping wages records and ordered to pay arrears within 7 days.

MainHeading.P: It is not the policy of my Department to publish the names and addresses of employers against whom proceedings are taken.

Premises covered by Joint Labour Committee Orders are inspected regularly by inspectors of my Department. Where breaches of Joint Labour Committee Orders are detected by inspectors in the course of those inspections, the employer concerned is first made aware of his responsibilities and asked to comply. This results in full compliance in the great majority of cases. Where compliance is not forthcoming, the question of instituting legal proceedings is put forward for consideration by the Department's legal advisers. A problem which can arise, particularly in the hotel and catering industries, is that employees are not willing to make statements and give evidence necessary for a successful prosecution and this is a factor which must obviously be taken into account when the question of instituting proceedings is being considered in individual cases.
